awd_abstract_narration:
The Frontier Probability Days (FPD) conference will be held at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, in Las Vegas, Nevada, from May 8 to 10, 2020. FPD, held approximately once every other year, is a conference that has rapidly established itself as the premier regional meeting in probability and its applications in the Intermountain West of the United States. 

The 2020 conference will be its seventh meeting. The conference schedule will be similar to that in recent meetings: There will be 7 one-hour plenary lectures, as well as 15-20 twenty-minute lectures. At least two of the plenary presentations will be dedicated to deep applications of probability theory in other important and exciting, as well as possibly-emerging, scientific disciplines. The conference is expected to host 70-80 participants in FDP 2020. Seven distinguished mathematicians, at the forefront of several different areas with probability and its applications, have accepted invitations to give plenary one-hour talks. The 20-minutes lectures are made to encourage early career researchers, women, and minority-group representatives to speak and showcase their work. The conference website is maintained at: http://lechen.faculty.unlv.edu/FPD20/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Frontier Probability Days was a three day conference held from December 3-5, 2021, at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas. Its main purpose was to bring together leading regional and national researchers in probability theory and its applications, especially young researchers and graduate students, to foster interaction and stimulate research activity. In these regards the 2021 edition was an unqualified success.


The conference featured six plenary speakers who presented research at the forefront of probability theory and its applications. Half of the plenary speakers described theoretical aspects on topics including mixing times for Markov chains, integrable probability, and stochastic homogenization/random walk in random environment. The other half focused on applications of probability theory to stochastics partial differential equations and network modeling via random hypergraphs. The focus on applications has become a prominent feature of Frontier Probability Days that distinguishes it from other regional probability conferences. The conference also included shorter talks from an additional 38 researchers, primarily students and beginning scholars. For young participants especially it was an excellent opportunity to highlight their latest research and sharpen their presentation skills. It also allowed young participants an opportunity to expand their network of potential collaborators and mentors, including to members of industry, especially the tech community.  A total of 60 people attended the conference over the three days.

The 2021 conference was the seventh iteration of Frontier Probability Days, with it previously being held in 2007 (Boulder), 2009, 2011, and 2016 (Utah), 2014 (Arizona), and 2018 (Oregon State). In this short time frame it has become the premier conference for probability research in the Intermountain West. In recent years this region has shown increased vitality in probability theory and its applications, and the focus of this conference series on applications has helped to broaden collaboration with other scientific fields. In turn, this collaboration has become a source of inspiration for more theoretical aspects of probability research.
